typedef mt::Singleton<HandleManager, false> nitf::HandleRegistry

Create a Singleton registry for managing the Handles

Note that this will NOT get deleted at exit, so there will be a memory loss the size of a HandleManager object (about 50 bytes). We can't let the singleton be deleted at exit, in case other singletons contain references to these handles.

Get the length

Get the tag

Set the tag

Get the TRE identifier. This is NOT the tag, however it may be the same value as the tag. The ID is used to identify a specific version/incarnation of the TRE, if multiple are possible. For most TREs, this value will be the same as the tag.

nitf::DECLARE_CLASS ( SegmentReader   ) 

Copy constructor

Assignment Operator

Set native object

nitf_SegmentReader_read - Read segment data

The nitf_SegmentReader_read function reads data from the associated segment. The reading of the data is serial as if a flat file were being read by an input stream. Except for the first argument, this function has the same calling sequence and behavior as IOInterface_read.

Parameters:
buffer buffer to hold data
count amount of data to return
seek - Seek in segment data

The nitf_SegmentReader_seek function allows the user to seek within the extension data. Except for the first argument, this function has the same calling sequence and behaivior as IOInterface_seek. The offset is relative to the top of the segment data.

The returned value maybe tested with NITF_IO_SUCCESS()

Parameters:
offset the seek offest
whence starting at (SEEK_SET, SEEK_CUR, SEEK_END)
Returns:
The offset from the beginning to the current position is set.
tell - Tell location in segment data

The tell function allows the user to determine the current offset within the extension data. Except for the first argument, this function has the same calling sequence and behaivior as IOInterface_tell. The offset is relative to the top of the segment data.

The returned value may be tested with NITF_IO_SUCCESS()

Returns:
The offset from the beginning to the current position is set.
getSize - Determine size of the data

The nitf_SegmentReader_seek function allows the user to determine the size of the data. Except for the first argument, this function has the same calling sequence and behavior as IOInterface_getSize.

The returned value maybe tested with NITF_IO_SUCCESS()

Returns:
The offset from the beginning to the current position is set.

Definition at line 41 of file SegmentReader.hpp.

nitf::DECLARE_CLASS ( List   ) 

Copy constructor

Assignment Operator

Set native object

Is our chain empty?

Returns:
True if so, False otherwise
Push something onto the front of our chain. Note, as usual we REFUSE to allocate your data for you. If you need a copy, make one up front.
Parameters:
data The data to push to the front
Push something onto the back of our chain
Parameters:
data The data to push onto the back
Pop the node off the front and return it. We check the first item to see if it exists. If it does, we then fill in, and return the value.
Returns:
The link we popped off
Pop the node off the back and return it. We check the first item to see if it exists. If it does, we then fill in, and return the value.
Returns:
The link we popped off
Constructor

Clone

Destructor

Get the begin iterator

Returns:
The iterator pointing to the first item in the list
Get the end iterator
Returns:
The iterator pointing to PAST the last item in the list (null);
Insert data into the chain BEFORE the iterator, and make the iterator point at the new node.

If the iterator is pointing to NULL, we will insert into the back of this list. If it is pointing to the beginning, we will insert into the front.

If the iterator is pointing to something else, we will insert after the iterator (same case, in practice as pointing to the beginning).

Parameters:
iter The iterator to insert before
data This is a pointer assignment, not a data copy
Remove the data from an arbitrary point in the list. This WILL NOT delete the data, but it will make sure that we have successfully updated the chain. The iterator is moved to the value that the current node pointed to (the next value).
Parameters:
where Where to remove, this will be updated to the NEXT position
Returns:
We don't know how to delete YOUR object, so return it.
Get the first

Get the last

Returns the size of the list

Returns the data at the given index

nitf::DECLARE_CLASS ( ImageSubheader   ) 

Copy constructor

Assignment Operator

Set native object

Constructor

Clone

Destructor

Set the pixel type and band related information

Parameters:
pvtype Pixel value type
nbpp Number of bits/pixel
abpp Actual number of bits/pixel
justification Pixel justification
irep Image representation
icat Image category
bandCount Number of bands
bands Band information object list
Deprecated:
  • here for backwards compatibility bandCount WILL get ignored

This function allows the user to set the corner coordinates from a set of decimal values. This function only supports CornersTypes of NITF_GEO or NITF_DECIMAL. Others will trigger an error with code NITF_ERR_INVALID_PARAMETER

In order to set up the type, you should declare a double corners[4][2]; The first dimension is used for the corner itself, and the second dimension is for lat (0) or lon (1).

The corners MUST be oriented to correspond to

corners[0] = (0, 0), corners[1] = (0, MaxCol), corners[2] = (MaxRow, MaxCol) corners[3] = (MaxRow, 0)

following in line with 2500C.

This function allows the user to extract corner coordinates as a set of decimal values. This function only supports CornersTypes of NITF_GEO or NITF_DECIMAL. Others will trigger an error with code NITF_ERR_INVALID_PARAMETER

The output corners will be oriented to correspond to

corners[0] = (0, 0), corners[1] = (0, MaxCol), corners[2] = (MaxRow, MaxCol) corners[3] = (MaxRow, 0)

following in line with 2500C.

Get the type of corners. This will return NITF_CORNERS_UNKNOWN in the event that it is not 'U', 'N', 'S', 'D', or 'G'.

Set the image dimensions and blocking info. The user specifies the number of rows and columns in the image, number of rows and columns per block, and blocking mode. The number of blocks per row and column is calculated. The NITF 2500C large block option can be selected for either dimension by setting the corresponding block dimension to 0.

Parameters:
numRows The number of rows
numCols The number of columns
numRowsPerBlock The number of rows/block
numColsPerBlock The number of columns/block
imode Image mode
Set the image dimensions and blocking.

The blocking is set to the simplest possible blocking given the dimension, no blocking if possible. Blocking mode is set to B. Whether or not blocking masks are generated is dependent on the compression code at the time the image is written. NITF 2500C large block dimensions are not set by this function. The more general set blocking function must be used to specify this blocking option.

Parameters:
numRows The number of rows
numCols The number of columns
Get the number of bands

Create new bands

Insert the given comment at the given index (zero-indexed);

Remove the given comment at the given index (zero-indexed);

nitf::DECLARE_CLASS ( HashTable   ) 

Copy constructor

Assignment Operator

Set native object

Constructor

Parameters:
nbuckets The size of the hash
Clone

This function controls ownership. You may elect either policy, NITF_DATA_ADOPT, or NITF_DATA_RETAIN_OWNER. Here is the difference. In the hash table, the data field is a pointer to an object. That object may have been allocated by you, or it may be static, I don't know. You may wish to remove it yourself, or I may be told to remove it for you. If you do not tell me, I will assume that you own it.

Remove data from the hash table. Here is the removal policy: You ask for this object to be removed from the hash

  • We remove the pair from the hash and delete the pair associated with the storage
  • We give you back your data, if it exists
  • You are expected to delete the data we give you

Assigns the hash function to a "good" default.

Check to see whether such a key exists in the table

Parameters:
The key to lookup
Returns:
True if exists, False otherwise.
Debug tool to find out whats in the hash table

For each item in the hash table, do something (slow);

Parameters:
fn The function to perform
Insert this key/data pair into the hash table
Parameters:
key The key to insert under
data The data to insert into the second value of the pair
Templated insert, allowing us to insert nitf::Objects

Retrieve some key/value pair from the hash table

Parameters:
key The key to retrieve by
Returns:
The key/value pair
Get the buckets

Get the nbuckets

Get the adopt flag

Get the begin iterator

Returns:
The iterator pointing to the first item in the list
Get the end iterator
Returns:
The iterator pointing to PAST the last item in the list (null);
Clear the buckets

Definition at line 174 of file Extensions.hpp.

nitf::DECLARE_CLASS ( DownSampler   ) 

Copy constructor

Assignment Operator

Set native object

Applies a sampling method while reading.

Parameters:
inputWindow The input image fragment
outputWindow A sub-sampled image fragment
numWindowRows How many rows for the input window
numWindowCols How many cols for the input window
numInputCols Number of columns in input buffer, full res
numSubWindowCols The number of columns in the sub-window
pixelType The pixel type (valid values found in System layer)
pixelSize The size of one pixel
rowsInLastWindow The number of rows in the final window
colsInLastWindow The number of cols in the final window
Note: The numWindowRows, numWindowCols, and numSubWindowCols values are in output image units (units of sample windows). For example, with a pixel skip of 3 in columns, if the sub-window request spans columns 0-299, then numSubWindowCols is 100. If the block is such that a particular request spans columns 90-149 (60 full resolution columns), then numWindowCols is 20. The numInputCols value is in full resolution units. This value gives the length, in pixels, of one row in the input buffer. This buffer is used for all down sample calls. Since the number of windows can vary from call to call, this buffer has a worst case length. Therefore, it is not possible to move from one row to the next with just the number of sample windows per row (numWindowCols) for the current request.

Allows the engine to call the apply function for this object

Needed for the engine interface

Get the down sampler interface

Constructor
